abstracts.cdata!:
Although the project outcome was
            satisfactory, sustainability is uncertain, given its
            critical dependability on the sector's long-term
            financial viability, a problem which will increase as rural
            electrification expands to areas with lesser demand, which
            in turn, is dependable on successful sector reforms in
            tariff regulation, and privatization. In addition, the
            institutional development impact was negligible, due to the
            unexpected institutional development in the management
            contract component, particularly as marginal improvements
            reversed commercial performance indicators. Lessons
            stipulate that: 1) large utility expansion programs require
            financial sustainability, to sustain operations, and
            maintenance once the investment is completed, in addition to
            reforms to improve the prospects of financial viability.
            However, experience suggests that independent regulation
            takes much longer to take root, whereas a tariff regime
            allowing for automatic adjustments may help alleviate the
            overall problem; 2) the design of management contracts,
            needs to grant autonomy to contractors to implement
            decisions, and measures for improving performance
            indicators, as well as payments to contractors should be
            linked to specific measurable outcomes, with baseline
            performance indicators, verifiable unambiguously, to
            facilitate performance evaluation; and, 3) a new rural
            energy strategy needs to be developed, to provide an
            enabling policy framework, and low-cost design standards for
            the sub-transmission, and distribution works. Additional
            issues, underline adequate procurement arrangements, and
            development of domestic contractor capacity.
